title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What are some areas where probability is often applied?

options.label: B
options.text: Standardized tests, lotteries, casinos, and auto insurance rates

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental counting principle used for?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the number of possible outcomes when events are paired or to find the number of ways to arrange outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate the probability of getting all questions correct

options.label: D
options.text: To find the number of ways to arrange outcomes

multiple-choice.question: If you toss a fair coin 10 times to choose answers for a true/false quiz, what is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing?
How many ways can you write down different combinations of Ts and Fs for a 10-question true/false quiz?

options.label: D
options.text: Too many to count and list by hand

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a question right by guessing on a standardized test?
What is the average score you would get right by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If there are 20 questions and five possible answers for each question on a standardized test, what is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?
What is the number of possible outcomes for each question on a standardized test?
What is the most common score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?

options.label: C
options.text: More than 10 out of the 10 questions correct

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected score you would get right by guessing on a 20-question standardized test?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a standardized test?
What is the number of possible outcomes for a 20-question true/false quiz?
What term is used to describe personal stories that connect people and make a story timeless and humanistic?
What is the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: A combination of official, overview, and unofficial sources

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of official sources, stakeholders, and experts

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of overview sources, unofficial sources, and academics

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of official sources, unofficial sources, and consultants

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources are included in the second side of the trifecta of sourcing?
What type of sources are included in the third side of the trifecta of sourcing?
What is the purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: To identify what is compelling from what is chatter

options.label: D
options.text: To achieve a deeper understanding of the subject

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe personal anecdotes that add depth and emotion to a story?
When is it most important to convey information quickly in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: When a situation is routine and does not require immediate attention

options.label: B
options.text: When a situation is urgent and action is required now

options.label: C
options.text: When a story is complex and requires a slow dance of information

options.label: D
options.text: When a story is trivial and does not require much attention

multiple-choice.question: What type of journalism benefits from a slow dance of information?
What is the purpose of the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a well-rounded and comprehensive story

options.label: D
options.text: To achieve a deeper understanding of the subject

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the connection that journalists aim to make between people through their stories?

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away"?
According to the text, what can stories change in a person?

options.label: B
options.text: Their sense of class and social status

multiple-choice.question: Which novel, published in the 18th century, challenged many traditions and caused a ruckus?
According to Darwin's theory of evolution, what are privileged?
According to recent studies, what might be wrong about our sense of being a hero?

options.label: A
options.text: We might be hardwired for competition

options.label: B
options.text: We might be members of a shared quest

multiple-choice.question: Why should we travel with Dickens, let Pip teach us what to expect from ourselves?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we should learn from the classics and understand how the terrain has changed

options.label: B
options.text: Because we haven't walked just one mile in Jane Austen's or Mark Twain's shoes - we've walked about 100 trillion miles in them

options.label: C
options.text: Because Pip is a great teacher

options.label: D
options.text: Because we should travel with Dickens

multiple-choice.question: What might "Hunger Games" lead us to think about capitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a fair system

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a corrupt system

options.label: C
options.text: That it pits individuals against each other in a fight for survival

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a system that benefits the individual

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of "Uglies"?

options.label: A
options.text: The dangers of pursuing a perfect physical appearance

multiple-choice.question: What might "Seekers" reflect?

options.label: A
options.text: The dangers of global warming and the importance of conservation

multiple-choice.question: What is the final question?

options.label: A
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the meaning of life?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the purpose of stories?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the point of reading?

multiple-choice.question: What idea are scholars discovering evidence for?

options.label: A
options.text: That stories have a unique ability to change a person's point of view

options.label: C
options.text: That much of what we believe about life comes not from fact, but from fiction

multiple-choice.question: Who is an example of a thought leader whose theory of evolution is highly indebted to the plots he read and loved?

options.label: D
options.text: Samuel Richardson is mentioned as a thought leader, but Darwin is the correct answer.

multiple-choice.question: According to the text, how many miles have we walked in the shoes of authors like Jane Austen and Mark Twain?
What is the main idea of the passage?

options.label: A
options.text: That stories can change a person's point of view

options.label: B
options.text: That stories shape culture and influence our beliefs

options.label: C
options.text: That stories have the power to change the world

multiple-choice.question: According to the text, what is one of the dangers of pursuing a perfect physical appearance, as seen in the novel "Uglies"?

options.label: D
options.text: The pressure to conform to societal standards

multiple-choice.question: What concept is used to deal with rather small numbers or extremely large numbers?
What is the relationship between the base number, b, and the exponent, p, in the equation b raised to the p power, equals n?

options.label: A
options.text: b is the result of p divided by n

options.label: B
options.text: n is the result of p divided by b

options.label: C
options.text: b raised to the p power equals n

options.label: D
options.text: b divided by p equals n

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
Why is it necessary to study logarithms even though a calculator can compute them?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the concept of logarithms

options.label: B
options.text: To learn how to use a calculator

options.label: C
options.text: To apply logarithms to different bases

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the history of logarithms

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH formula to calculate the acidity or basicity of a sample?

options.label: A
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration plus 1

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration minus 1

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a pH of 8.4 on human eyes?
What is the relationship between the base, the exponent, and the number in the equation "log base b of some number n equals p"?

options.label: A
options.text: The base raised to what power equals the number?

options.label: B
options.text: The base times the power equals the number

options.label: C
options.text: The base divided by the power equals the number

options.label: D
options.text: The power divided by the base equals the number

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 2 of 64?
What is the effect of a pH of 7.4 on human eyes?
What is the use of logarithms in chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the pH of water samples

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the temperature of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions

options.label: D
options.text: To calculate the concentration of oxygen

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the pH of a sample and the pH of human tears?

options.label: B
options.text: The pH of the sample is lower than the pH of human tears

options.label: C
options.text: The pH of the sample is higher than the pH of human tears

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relationship between the pH of the sample and the pH of human tears

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a calculator on the need to study logarithms?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes it unnecessary to study logarithms

options.label: B
options.text: It makes it more difficult to study logarithms

options.label: C
options.text: It makes it easier to study logarithms

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the need to study logarithms

multiple-choice.question: What is the correct representation of the concept of logarithms?

options.label: A
options.text: log base b of some number n equals p

options.label: B
options.text: log base b of some number n equals n

options.label: C
options.text: log base b of some number n equals b

options.label: D
options.text: log base b of some number n equals p plus n

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH of a water sample with a hydrogen ion concentration of 0.0000000398?
What is the pH of a water sample with a hydrogen ion concentration of 0.00000000398?

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known form of telling time?

options.label: A
options.text: Obelisks from nearly 5,000 years ago, which used sundials to indicate time by casting a shadow onto a surface.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the object that casts a shadow on a sundial?

options.label: A
options.text: Gnomon, a stick in the center of the sundial.

multiple-choice.question: Why do sundials have limitations?

options.label: A
options.text: They require the sun to shine, making them unusable at night.

multiple-choice.question: What methods were used to estimate the passage of time before the invention of the mechanical clock?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundials, hourglasses, candles, and sticks of incense were used to estimate the passage of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: Atomic clocks, which are used to keep a continuous count of seconds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a time zone?

options.label: C
options.text: To iron out differences in time between locations, allowing for smoother communication and coordination.

multiple-choice.question: How many time zones are there on land?

options.label: C
options.text: 24 time zones are used on land, but some sources may group them differently, resulting in 40 or more time zones.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to keep track of time?

options.label: B
options.text: It regulates our daily lives, making it possible to accurately communicate with people all over the world.

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem with the American railroad system before the use of time zones?

options.label: C
options.text: Each railroad used its own standard time, leading to confusion and missed connections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate difference in time between New York and Boston?
